content.statement: A category C consists of a collection of objects and a collection of morphisms (arrows) between objects, equipped with composition and identity operations satisfying associativity and identity laws.

explanation.intuition: A category is a mathematical universe where objects exist and arrows connect them. What matters isn't what the objects are, but how the arrows compose - just as in navigation, the connections between places matter more than the places themselves.
explanation.key_insight: Categories shift focus from objects to relationships. The essence of mathematical structure lies not in the objects themselves but in how they relate through morphisms.
explanation.technical_details: Formally, a category C comprises: (1) A collection ob(C) of objects, (2) For each pair of objects A,B a collection hom(A,B) of morphisms from A to B, (3) For morphisms f: A→B and g: B→C, a composition g∘f: A→C, (4) For each object A, an identity morphism idₐ: A→A.

formal_definition.latex: \text{A category } \mathcal{C} \text{ consists of:} \\ \text{1. Objects: } \text{ob}(\mathcal{C}) \\ \text{2. Morphisms: } \text{hom}_{\mathcal{C}}(A,B) \text{ for each } A,B \in \text{ob}(\mathcal{C}) \\ \text{3. Composition: } \circ : \text{hom}(B,C) \times \text{hom}(A,B) \to \text{hom}(A,C) \\ \text{4. Identity: } \text{id}_A \in \text{hom}(A,A) \text{ for each } A
components: Morphisms: hom_C(A,B) for each pair A,B
Composition: (g: B→C, f: A→B) ↦ g∘f: A→C
Identity: id_A: A→A for each object A
